title: Gradescope test is_monotonicish
body: For the gradescope test is_monotonicish([1, 2, 3, 4 , 3, 2, 1]) it says expected: 'True'. In the function specs comment one of the conditions says: (a) the last number must be greater than the first. It appears that the gradescope test doesn't match up with the function specifications, but maybe I am missing something.

lastMessage.body: I noticed this problem too. Could someone from the staffs please clarify this? Thank you!

comments.body: Should we write our code to the gradescope tests or the descriptions in the python starter code. I altered my function form the "last number must be greater than the first" to "the last number must be greater than or equal to the first." and vice versa for monotonically decreasing. This has made it so I past that previously failing test, and it also does not cause a any other tests form starting to fail. I don't know if that is the correct solution, but at least you get the points on gradescope, but I don't know if that is the behavior we want for this function.

Good catch.  There was indeed a problem with the autograder.  The example you included above should be false, since the first and last elements are equal.

Should be fixed on Gradescope now; let me know if you're still getting the issue.

title: Explanation of consistency in heuristics
body:
"A consistent heuristic function means that the values of
f(n) along any path are non-decreasing" is what is said on the slide, but I'm not exactly sure what that means for h(n).

comments.body:
In the example of graph-searching problem,  for arbitrary node `N` and its arbitrary successor `P` in the graph, the heuristic value `f(N)` of this node given by consistent heuristic functions `f( )`, is no greater than the step `cost` of getting to `P` plus `f(P)` ( where `f(P)` is the heuristics value of node `P`).

![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

If the heuristics functions satisfies this condition, we say this heuristics functions is `consistent heuristic function`. If not, we don't. 
HTH. :)

title: Iterative deepening search clarification
body:
I'm a bit confused what it means on slide 25 of lecture 2 that IDS is optimal if step costs are identical. 

Is step costs referring to how much the max depth to search to increases from iteration to iteration or does it refer to the transition cost between each state? 

Edit: 

If it means the cost of the transition. Doesn't the optimality also depend on how you increase the depth to go to , k , each time? I can see how for cases where you always increase the depth by 1 and all transitions have cost 1, it'll  be the optimal solution. 

However, if you increased the value of k by some number greater than the transition cost each time, don't you run the possibility finding a solution greater than the optimal solution?

comments.body: I think it means transition between states
Your reasoning sounds correct.  You do indeed run the risk of  finding a non-optimal path if you increase k by more than 1.

title: Consistent Hueristic
body:
Hello,

I'm kinda confused on what this means exactly. The slides say it means that "the values of f(n) along any path are non-decreasing". 

Can someone first explain the difference between h(n) and f(n) in A* and then explain what this definition is saying? 

That would be greatly appreciated!
-Thanks

comments.body: When a heuristic functions is admissible and consistent, it will have these features in #41. Comment if you have further question, and hope this helps.

Thank you for taking the time to answer. Follow up:
If f(n) and h(n) are the same thing, how would it be non-decreasing along any path? Doesn't the heuristic get smaller and smaller as you get closer to the goal?

Thanks

I apologize for my mistake, `h()` and `f()` are not the same things, which are described in page `67`.
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

"A consistent heuristic function means that the values of f(n) along any path are non-decreasing". 

We now know `f(n) = g(n) + h(n)` so far, given by the definitions above. The reason why `f(n)` is non-decreasing, is because for any node, let say `n`, there will be `f(n) = g(n) + h(n)`, where `h(n)` is a heuristic value, an `ideal`, lowest cost from `n` to `Goal` (it can be the straight-line distance as slides define).  And, for any node that you are walking through from the starting node to goal node, the `f(n)` will at least be non-decreasing, due to the real cost from the current node to goal node is always non-lower than the heuristic of current node (it can be equal, when this heuristic is perfect).

Sry for my mistake before again, and hope this helps.

title: Does greedy best-search ever push a goal state?
body: When greedy best-first search reaches a goal state, does the goal state get pushed then popped, or does it just terminate immediately? I figured that it  just ends upon reaching a goal state, but can't confirm this in the textbook or lecture slides.

conversation.name: Does greedy best-search ever push a goal state?

comments.body: For greedy best (and other cost based searches) the goal state first gets pushed onto the frontier and then has to be popped in order to consider the search "complete". That is because even though it may on the frontier, its weight/priority can be updated in the priority queue if we find a path with a lower cost.

title: How do we get the priority from each element for USC?
body: I've been trying to assign the priority to each element for the implementation of UCS, but I can't find out how. What gives each task their priority, and how can I assign it to the frontier?

conversation.name: How do we get the priority from each element for USC?

comments.body:
If, by chance, you are inheriting `BreadthFirstSolver`, you will have to change the frontier to `PriorityQueue`.

If you are using `PriorityQueue` class from `pdpq.py`, you can assign the priority in `PriorityQueue` by doing using `add(task, priority=p)` where `p` is your priority. 

Take a look into `pdpq.py` for more details.

Thank you for answering so fast. I did that before, but when I do priority=self.frontier.get() it doesn't work, instead it returns the string of numbers. Maybe I'm not understanding where the priority is coming from.

In the case of UCS, the priority is the cost to a given node. We can get the cost to a given node using the ```get_cost``` function in the BFS class. BFS does not use this function but it was implemented there so other classes can inherit it or if you just want to copy it over for the other classes.

So say I have some state ```s``` and I want to add it to the frontier. Firstly, we will have the frontier be a ```PriorityQueue```, so say we do ```frtr = pdqpq.PriorityQueue()```. Then to get the cost of our state ```s``` we can use the ```get_cost``` function. Lastly, we can add it to the frontier with the cost/priority (they are the same in this case) ny doing what Mathew said with ```frtr.add(s, self.get_cost(s))```.

```priority=self.frontier.get()``` is missing an agreement inside the ```get()```. So say we want to get the priority of something **already** in the frontier. From our example before if we wanted to get the cost of the ```s``` we'd do ```s_priority = frtr.get(s)```.
Thank you for your thorough response, I got it to work and it's pretty close to what the professor had in class, so I guess I just need to polish it now. I hope you both have a good weekend.

title: Conflicting information in textbook and lecture slides
body:
Hello, in the lecture slides, it states that greedy best first search is always complete in a finite state space. But in the textbook, page 93, it states

*Greedy best-first tree search is also incomplete even in a finite state space, much like
depth-first search.*

title: Choosing Min/Max
body: Sorry if this has been discussed before but when we bubble up our way to the root in a minimax algorithm, how can we choose what order of min/max we have to follow? I saw both min and the max at the root in the lecture in two different scenarios so I am a bit confused.

comments.body: You need to alternate between min and max at every depth level. At the root, it's min or max depending on the game and the player. If the player for whom we are calculating the minmax strategy wants to maximize the score for the given game, then the root node should be a max node.

title: Can we use lookahead recursively to explore states in deeper depth for Minimax?
body:
When we are limiting our lookahead to some depth, is it possible to use recursion and go deeper in the tree for optimal state?

Also, would there be any change in performance if we did separate multiple searches on the branches at the same time? Like dividing the tree into pieces and making separate searches simultaneously? I am not sure if we can do that, but I was wondering.

conversation.name: Can we use lookahead recursively to explore states in deeper depth for Minimax?

comments.body:
Without looking at all the unpruned the leaf values, it would be hard for you to know which series of moves is optimal. You could set the lookahead limit to the height of the tree, but that would be very expensive. In most cases, you're better off coming up with a clever evaluation function that will give you a good guess. 

Yes, there are ways to parallelize minimax that would speed up computation. In this case, our autograder doesn't support parallelization, so I wouldn't try it for this assignment. I do like the direction in which you're thinking, though. :)

"Note: This cannot be "return state.utility() + c", where c is a constant. "

title: State Generation Count
body:
Hello I just had a quick question regarding the counts of generated states. So with the provided code in connect383.py .successors() will generate all of the successors for a state and increment the generated count with the total number of successors generated. Now with this example in class:
![fffe4485810dc181d2e1b12340360867.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

In the middle state in the second row when we call .successors() our generated state count is increased by 3, but we do not explore the right most successor state due to pruning. In the most optimal case it seems better to generate successors 1 at a time and increment the count by 1 each time. This would cause us to not generate the last state since the pruning would occur prior and our generated states would only increment by 2. 

Is it fine that our generated count is being increased by 3 even if we are not exploring that last state at all since our count is counting generated states rather than explored states, and .successors() automatically increases the count when states are generated, or are we expected to find a way to generate these successor states one by one and only increase the generated count when a single state is generated?

Edit: In the comments of the code it states "N.B.: When exploring the game tree and expanding nodes, you must consider the child nodes
        in the order that they are returned by GameState.successors()." So it seems like we are expected to use .succesors() and the number of generated states would be incremented by 3 for the example above. And I believe this is also what the comment means by stating "we're trading optimality for gradeability here"

comments.body:
Good catch! Ideally, the `.successors()` function should have returned an iterator instead of an array of all successors. So yes, according to the provided code, the generated states count will get incremented by 3 for example you mentioned.
But it shouldn't be a big deal because the entire subtree below that 3rd successor will not be generated and will not add to the count. In the grand scheme of things, that extra count of one state won't matter.
Thank you!

title: MinimaxLookahead depth clarification
body: If the depth limit = the game tree depth, do we call the evaluation function, or just return the utility of the node. I see no point in returning evaluation, since if were already at the end of the tree we might as well take the most accurate way and return the utility instead, since the utility of a leaf node is the true value. For connect383, it also stands to reason that all leaf nodes are also at the same depth for any board, since it plays until both players have no moves left.

title: Rules for obstacles?
body:
Hello,

I'm confused on the rules for how the blocker pieces work. In a separate post I saw that blocker pieces can be placed at the top of the board, but when I run a test like:
\[\[-2, -2\],
\[0, 0\]\]

with random and human the code given by the project isn't able to detect that the board is full.

Running this board:
\[\[-2, -2, 0\],
\[0, 0, 0\],
\[0, 0, 0\]\]

with human and random uses only supplied code, and gives an error after the right column is filled. 

What exactly are the rules for blocker pieces? The instructions say that they are "obstacle pieces" so that implies to me that the same rules apply to them as regular player pieces do, so they should only be able to be placed like regular pieces and can't float / be at the top of the board. 

Can I please get some clarification?

Thanks!

comments.body:
Which post are you referring to?
My understanding is that blocker pieces cannot float and the examples you mention are invalid boards.
I will confirm this with the prof.
The replies in post #294 a TA in the comments said that a board with floating pieces is legal.

I see. The problem is that the supplied code detects that the board is full by checking if `_moves_left<=0`. The game is initialized with `_moves_left` = number of 0s in the initial board. As a result, the code is implicitly assuming that the blocker pieces don't float.
So, in the first example you mention, the game is initialized with `_moves_left=2`. That's why it is unable to detect that the board is full.

Thanks for catching this edge case!

But anyway, we won't test your code on boards with floating obstacles.
Great, thanks for clarifying!
Update: I'll make sure there aren't floating obstacles in the test cases since that doesn't work with the rest of the code.

body: Does a 0 on the board represent an empty space?

comments.body: Yes

Are you sure? If you look at the board without any moves when running something like 3x3, all the empty spaces are represented by '-' and 0 represents a move by player 2. Could the course staff chime in here?

In boards.py empty spaces are represented with a 0. When boards are printed into the console empty spaces are represented with a -. A move for player 1 is represented with 1 in boards.py and in the console output will be an X. For player 2 its -1 in boards.py and a O in the output.

body:

title: Question 3a: Tautology Logic Question
body:
Why is this true when p is false and q is true.

![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

comments.body: If you have P -> Q this is logically equivalent to ~P V Q by implication elimination. It is clear here that any false value for P will turn into true by the negation. So no matter what Q is this statement will return true since true ORed with anything is true.

title: Homework 4 conditional probability question
body: I have a question about conditional probability in the Bayesian network presented in homework 4. While we are not explicitly asked to calculate this value, I'm confused about the conditional probability of M=true given that P=true. Would it not be the sum of P(M=true | P=true,E=false) and P(M=true | P=true,E=true), which equates to 0.7 + 0.5 = 1.2? Why am I getting a probability value that is > 1 here? A clarification would help my understanding of Bayesian networks - much appreciated. Here is the network for ease of reference: ![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

comments.body:
Conditional probabilities can be a little tricky. Perhaps E doesn't influence M very much, so P(M=true | P=true, E) doesn't decrease as much you might think when E is false. 

This thread gives a better intuition behind conditional probabilities: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/294580/intuition-behind-the-definition-of-conditional-probability-for-2-events.

title: HW4 code Error
body:
I ran "python3 bayes_awesome.py" and received this error : 

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "CS383/383_homework4_2/bayes_awesome.py", line 2, in <module>
    from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'matplotlib'
```

I did "pip install matplotlib " but that did not help.

comments.body: That might be happening because Python is unable to locate Matplotlib on your computer even though you've installed it. I've gotten this error many times while working with Python libraries and I usually get around it by setting up a new virtual environment for each project. You can follow the steps [here](https://programwithus.com/learn/python/pip-virtualenv-mac) to create one. It should take a minute or two. In case it still doesn't work, you might want to change your interpreter path. The option to do that is usually at the bottom right of VS Code. Hope this helps!

So I created a Virtual environment , using the following steps (I have a mac for anyone who is curious)

(Steps done inside HW 4 folder)
pip install virtualenv
sudo /usr/bin/easy_install virtualenv
virtualenv venv

But after doing 
```
pip install matplotlib
``` 
I still was not able to get rid of the error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'matplotlib'
```
I think you forgot to activate the virtual environment as mentioned on the webpage. After doing virtualenv env, you have to do source env/bin/activate.

I was able to fix it without doing the virtual environment at all and just did 

```
python3 -m pip install matplotlib
```

https://bobbyhadz.com/blog/python-no-module-named-matplotlib
Mine seems to be stuck on preparing metadata (setup.py) for some reason. Did it take a long time for this phase?

title: Homework 4 calculations
body: I am getting tripped up on part (c) of the calculations portion where it asks to find the marginal probability of M = true. I initially thought to sum over all instances of m being true but that is just every entry in the table which would be far greater than one. if anyone could offer any suggestions of how to go about this problem it would be greatly appreciated!

comments.body:
Try using the following identity: 

If $$A$$ is a parent of $$B$$,
$$P(B=b) = \sum_{a \in \{true, false\}} P(A=a)P(B=b|A=a) $$

Or if there are two parents $$A_1, A_2$$,
$$P(B=b) = \sum_{a_1} \sum_{a_2} P(A_1=a_1, A_2=a_2)P(B=b|A_1=a_1,A_2=a_2) $$
If I understand correctly, you are summing up the rows where M=true. But you need a weighted sum, with a row's weight being the probably of that row itself being true.

What would happen in the case that $$A_1$$ is a parent of $$A_2$$ when calculating ![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)
​?
Then A1 and A2 are not independent. In that case, joint probability P(A1, A2) = P(A1)P(A2|A1).

title: Independence Clarification from Fri. OH
body:
Hi all,

I wanted to give additional clarification about debates students had during office hours about independence.

Namely, student were asking if we have ![Screen%20Shot%202022-11-04%20at%203.56.38%20PM.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)
and we are asked to calculate P(B|A,E), why can't we do P(B|A,E)=P(B|A).

I said to simply look at the math to figure out why, but since students were a bit dissatisfied with that I'll explain further.

If $$P(B|A,E)=P(B|A)$$ then the following would need to hold:
$$P(B|A,E)=P(B,A,E)/P(A,E)=P(B,A)P(E)/(P(A)P(E))=P(B,A)/P(A)=P(B|A)$$ When I say look at the math, I mean think about why we cannot have $$P(B,A,E)/P(A,E)=P(B,A)P(E)/(P(A)P(E))$$ in the example above. I'd suggest reviewing lectures 12 and 13 (slide 38 helps with the overall question) to answer this.

As an additional note, I accidentally said in my office hours that B is independent from E if given A. I was mixing up some concepts and that is incorrect, see lecture 13 slide 38 to see why it is dependent.

lastMessage.body: Sorry the comment was an accident

title: Question about independence
body:
![Screen%20Shot%202022-11-04%20at%205.17.48%20PM.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

Is A and C Independent from each other in graphs A and B?

comments.body:
Are you asking about the independence relationship of A and C or A and B?

If it's the former: is there a d-connecting path between A and C in each graph, given B?
Sorry for the mismatch I am asking between A and C. Based on nick's words. A and C are dependent in Graph B given B and independent in graph A given B. Am I right?

![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)
Check out slide 36 from lecture 13. X means independent and B is given in this slide.
Thanks, in graph 2 there is a D-connection means dependent. In graph one there are no d-connection means independent. Is this ok?
Yes.  Technically a d-connecting path means "non-independent", but you are correct.

title: Question on d-connectedness
body: In the causal DAG, we have a directed edge from Palate to Moxie, for example. So are these nodes d-connected or does it depend on which node you start from? Because starting from Moxie, there is no path back to Palate.

comments.body:
From lect 13 slide 28: "Two nodes (or sets of nodes) A and B are d-connected if there exists an **undirected**, collider-free path between A and B; otherwise they are d-separated".

So if the path is collider-free, direction and, therefore, where we start from does not matter.
But isn't the path between Palate and Moxie directed (though it's collider-free)? Or do we simply assume that if there are no collisions that we can start the path from either node?

Sort of like the latter. Direction still matters for calculating the actual probabilities. But for d-connection either is fine. This slide from lecture 13 might help more ![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)
In that case, doesn't that mean that 2b and 2e in the primer are basically the same question?
Not exactly since in 2E we are asking about Enrolled.
Sorry, I meant 2b and 2d. Wouldn't they be basically asking the same question?

Oh, they are similar but 2D is asking what if we now know P and M so your answer might be different. This slide might help.

![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

Hi, I'm fairly sure that is not the issue. I updated the None statement after looking on campuswire. My initial submission cannot return None in the SimpleSampler.getProb Function and still has the same issue. Also, I am fairly sure the error "is not defined" refers to being unable to access a variable since it doesn't exist, not that it is None.

```
Exception occurred while performing SimpleSampler.get_prob on:

Traceback information for debugging:
```

title: Homework 5 coding
body: For the 0th iteration, do we initialize the utility values to the rewards or would we initialize utility values for every state to 0.

comments.body: The cool thing is that it will work either way; for the homework, you should mirror what is done in the Primer.

title: Homework 5 primer, terminal state utility
body: Should we update the utility value of the terminal state?

comments.body:
No.  The utility of terminal states doesn't change.

The reason for this: the utility is defined as the expected rewards from that state from the current step to the end of the episode.  Since the episode necessarily ends at terminal states, there are no future rewards, so the utility is always equal to the current (terminal state) reward.

title: Value Iteration Clarification
body:
I just have a quick question regarding value iteration. In the slides and based on the pseudocode it states that we Initialize all non-terminal-state utilities U(s) to 0.00. On the primer for the homework it seems like we initialized all of these values to their reward values rather than 0. Which way should we implement this when it comes to the coding portion of the homework? I am asking as the results will be affected I can get the same results as the primer if I set the default reward to -1 and then initialize the utilities to their reward values, but my output differs if I handle it the way that the pseudocode and slides do with initializing to 0.

Edit (follow up question): And I just want to make sure in the case of terminal states we initialize their values to the reward correct? And those values then would not be updated at all through the iteration since they are terminal states and would just remain their reward value throughout.

Thank you!

comments.body:
There seems to be some mixup between all the different ways value iteration is described. In lecture 17 slide 45 it says "(Initialize all non-terminal-state utilities U(s) to 0.00)" but the pseudocode in slide 40 tells you to set the utilities for all states to zero. I think slide 45 describes how we initialize in the hw. So what's happening in slide 45 is it is initializing all states to their reward and since all the non-terminal states have reward zero it says "(Initialize all non-terminal-state utilities U(s) to 0.00)".

Using our homework MDP as an example, if you initialize all non-terminal states as zero and the terminal state as its reward, you actually will end up with incorrect values. That's because $$U_1(2,2)$$ and $$U_1(3,1)$$ will be incorrectly calculated due to $$U_0(3,2)$$. So you have two options, you can initialize all states' utilities to their rewards or initialize all states' utilities as 0. If you initialize all states' utilities as 0 you'll notice that $$U_1(s)$$ is the reward at each state. 

Note that when we ask for the number of iterations we'll accept more than 1 answer since initializing all states' utilities as 0 means that you'll have one more iteration than if you initialized all states' as their rewards.

title: Policy Convergence Clarification
body:
"That is, at what iteration of value iteration did the policy generated by each iterations’ values stop changing?" 

Is this asking 
a) at which iteration did we start seeing the final policy 

or 

b) at which iteration was the policy the same as the one before it, and was the final policy. 


For example, if I had the policies after some number of iterations,  
0: up
1: up 
2: right 
3: down
4: down
5: down
...
infinity: down

Would the policy converge at the 3rd iteration or the 4th iteration in this case?

comments.body:
I would say b) is more accurate. Depending on how you interpret a), it could imply in your example that if we see "up" at iteration 21 and then "dow"n again until infinity, we might incorrectly give the answer of the 3rd or 4th iteration.

Either way, for your given example, 3rd or 4th would be fine. We made it so both answers are correct when grading.

title: HW5 Coding Question 3
body:
Question 3 states that:
"Modify the parameters in your code so that state (2, 2) has a reward of -100 and replace the None values for the variables gridworld, EPSILON, and discount_factor in the  q3()function in answers.py and run it."

However in the 4 multiple-choice options, they seem to keep mentioning that the state having the reward of -100 is state (1, 2) and not state (2, 2):

a.	Yes, because the resulting policy will always take actions that have a 0.0 chance of reaching state (1, 2) with the big bad reward of -100. 
b.	Yes, because the resulting policy will try to ensure that we reach the goal state as quickly as possible. 
c.	No, because the negative reward from the state (1,2) is not enough to change the actions taken by the original policy.
d.	No, because the original policy already took actions that have a 0.0 chance of reaching state (1, 2) with the big bad reward of -100. 

I'm just wondering if there is a typo error here and whether that should affect my final answer? Thank you!

title: Answer Sheet for D-Separation on HW4 Primer?
body:
Hello, could solutions be provided for the D-Separation Anxiety portion of the HW4 primer? I wish I knew the precise explanation as I would like to learn from my mistakes by reviewing it (and was potentially led astray discussing it in office hours/the forum). This could let me request a regrade. 

For example, for "Knowing nothing else about Yoshimi, do you expect that she is enrolled in 383?" My original thought was no, we do not have enough information to be certain of this. But then when I was told I could look at the probabilities in the tables for my answer, I said yes, because we see that P(E=true) is 0.8 which is significant and seemed reasonable that she likely is enrolled. I mean if there is a 0.8 belief it is raining I expect it'll rain and bring an umbrella. So I am perplexed that saying yes is incorrect and am wondering whether I misinterpreted the question, or the question was too vague, etc.

 Thus I would appreciate the details, thanks!

comments.body:
Normally, we don't post solution documents in case we want to reuse some questions, but feel free to ask about individual questions. 

In the case of part a, you are correct and should submit a regrade request.

These are the ones I need explanations for:

*a) Does learning that someone drinks Moxie affect your degree of belief that they have a good palate?*
- I said, “No, because while P and M are connected through P->M, conditioning on M does not block the path from P to M. Also knowing M alone does not tell us whether to believe P was the cause or not, as there is another possible cause E, so it would be different if we knew E too where P->M<-E would make P and E conditionally dependent and it may change with more evidence.”  
- I tried to get help on this in office hours as it confused me and I was told that my thought process of not blocking the path was sound and honestly am really not sure how else to use concepts of connectedness to answer this one? Just knowing someone drinks Moxie without knowing Enrolled, for example, does not make me think any differently about having a good palette. Unless this question specifically wants me to say Yes, that it would affect the degree of belief IF we also knew they were enrolled, which I made clear in my answer.

*b)Does learning that someone is excessively awesome affect your degree of belief that they have a good palate?*
- I said, “No, P and A are connected through P->M->A and conditioning on A does not block the path from P to A. Also knowing A alone without another condition like E being true does not provide enough evidence to increase or decrease my degree of belief.” 
- Similarly to a) I am confused why this is a “Yes.” Like multiple things cause A, why would just knowing A alone make me think anything different?

*d) You learn that the president of the Moxie Drinking Club has a bad palate. Does this affect your degree of belief that they are excessively awesome?*
- I said, “Yes, this would increase my belief that they are excessively awesome because M is a collider on P->M<-E where P and E are d-separated but evidence on M makes P and E conditionally dependent, so learning they have a bad palette increases the belief that being enrolled in 383 caused them to drink Moxie instead. Since the graph indicates BOTH E and M cause A, if we now expect the president is enrolled, we can especially think they are excessively awesome.”

- It’s like we know they drink moxie. And now we know that they are more likely to be enrolled that causes this instead of having a good palette due to conditional dependence based on evidence on M, and E and M both cause A, so I would think the belief increases. I don’t see why this is incorrect, I really tried to go back to the slides and directly follow the line of reasoning for the burglary/alarm example. And discussed it in office hours and it seemed like they were in agreement but clearly I am missing some big concept here.

Thanks!

title: value_iteration()
body: For this function, we calculate the utilities for one row only right? Since each state (x,y) has multiple utilities depending on its row (the table from question 2 in the primer) and we are required to return a dictionary where (x,y) is key and utility as value, I am wondering whether we calculate all utilities for all rows for each state or just one row. Thank you in advance!

comments.body: Each iteration of your value iteration code will be equivalent to calculating a "row" from the primer q2. So for example, after the first loop of your code, you will have the $$U_1(s)$$ row from the table. We want to calculate utilities until we converge (see pseudocode). So if that took say 42 iterations, then that means we'd have the table's rows 1-42.

title: Hack(H)er413 Applications are now open!
body:
Hi Everyone!

The Hack(H)er413 team would like to invite you all to participate in our fully in-person hackathon taking place on February 25th and 26th! 

Hack(H)er413 is a 24-hour student hackathon open to everyone, no matter your skill level, major, or gender identity. Our mission is to create a welcoming, inclusive and empowering environment for all women (cis and trans) and non-binary students. Students of all ethnic, gender identities, socioeconomic, and educational backgrounds are invited to come, innovate, learn, and feel safe while doing so! Participants get the opportunity to work with their peers in teams to make projects during the 24-hour window and compete for prizes in various categories. Hack(H)er413 is also hosting many workshops during the hackathon covering topics in hardware, software, and career development. Lastly, we will be hosting a career fair where students will get the opportunity to meet and network with representatives from our sponsor companies. 

We encourage anyone interested to apply right now at https://www.hackher413.com/! It is a wonderful opportunity to network with students and companies, learn new skills, and add projects to your resume. It’s also free! 

For any questions or concerns, feel free to email us at hackher413@gmail.com, and follow @hackher413 on Instagram for live updates.  

Sincerely,
The Hack(H)er413 Team

title: Question about Naive Bayes
body:
Hello, I am confused by two lecture slides for Naive Bayes Classifiers. 

Slide 52 lecture 19 says 

P(x1, x2, x3, … | spam) = P(x1 | spam) P(x2 | spam) P(x3 | spam)…

which can be simplified to 

P(attributes | spam) = P(attribute 1 | spam)P(attribute 2 | spam)...

But the next slide says 

P(class|attrs) = αP(attrs| class)P(class) = αP(class)
∏
i
P(attri| class)

As far as I can tell these are the exact same equations on the right side, but the conditional probabilities on the left are reversed. I.E P(attributes | class) became P(class | attributes) Why is this happening? Is this a typo?

comments.body:
$$P(class|attributes) = \frac{P(attributes|class) P(class)}{P(attributes)}$$ by Bayes Rule

We defined it so that $$\alpha = \frac{1}{P(attributes)}$$ as well as assuming all attributes are independent so $$P(attributes|class) = P(attr_1|class) *P(attr_2|class)...=\prod{P(attr_{i}|class)}$$

Substituting we get $$P(class|attributes) = \alpha P(class)\prod{P(attr_{i}|class)}$$

So the next slide hasn't quite reversed the conditions but used the simplification from the previous slide. Also, keep in mind that what we want is to find $$P(class|attributes)$$

title: HW4 Autograder Issue with None
body:
In #464 we're told that Rejection Sampling should return None when all samples are rejected. However, I failed the test which I believe was testing for this case when my code returns None, as gradescope says the input was query_vals: {'E': False}, evidence_vals: {'E': True}. I changed my code so that it would return 0 in this case, and submitted to the resubmission portal and was able to pass all the tests. 

I was wondering if this is a bug with the autograder or is this a special case where we should've returned 0? 

![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

comments.body:
P(E = False | E = True) is obviously zero, so hardcoding that value would get you to pass the test. But these variables are boolean so it's not very likely that you can collect a huge number of samples and still never get any that agree with the evidence (E = True).

I think the problem you described could happen if you are returning None in cases where both the assignments for random variables in the query (here E = False) and the evidence (here E = True) are not satisfied, instead of only rejecting based on the evidence.
I'm still a bit confused. The instructions seem to indicate we should never return a probability of 0, if the probability ends up being 0, it would instead return None.

In rejection sampling, you discard all samples that don't agree with the evidence (here E = True), and we do this as an approximation for conditioning on the evidence. If there are no samples with E = True to begin with, you would have to return None.

After that, you can count the number of remaining samples that agree with the query (here E = False). This way, you may have samples that agree with the evidence but none of them have E = False, and therefore return zero.
I see, I was confused by what the campuswire post meant by rejecting a sample. I thought rejecting all samples meant rejecting all of the remaining samples with the query.

I understand that at each split you should take the attribute that maximizes info gain, but what if the maximum amongst the attributes left is close to zero is there ever a point where it is not worth splitting given the gain?
I think if your info gain is never greater than 0 for that set of examples on all the attributes and splits, then you can just return a leaf node.

title: Gradescope Attribute Tests
body:
Hi,
It seems like the gradescope expects certain attributes to be in place for the root level and second level of the tree.

How is that possible? Shouldn't the attributes be different depending on the run? There should be variability in both the training/testing data split and the way we pick splits for numeric attributes.

Am I misunderstanding something?

Thanks!

comments.body:
I think I have the same issue leading me to fail only these test cases.
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

From what I understand, the way the autograder tests this is we train both your decision tree and our decision tree on the entire data set (no train/test splitting is done). Then, in theory, your tree should have the same structure as our tree.

You mentioned in office hours that the autograder seems to get different results sometimes. I looked into it and I believe you were seeing two different error messages. We have two checks, one that the `lt` node has the correct split attribute and another that the `ge` node has the correct split attribute. I think you were seeing two different error messages for different nodes at each level of the tree.
Your issue is more likely to be related to hardcoding attribute names for the election dataset instead of generalizing it to any dataset.

I have a feeling it might have to do with the way I handle data with "None" values for the feature I'm trying to split on. This was a little unclear in the instructions so do you mind confirming this?

When determining the information_gain for the split I completely ignore everything with a None value for that attribute, but then I add those to the child with more entries before passing it to the next recursive call.
I think you can just ignore the entries that are considered unknown (i.e. they don't end up in either of the children).
Thank you for letting me know. I think that was the issue. However, whatever the dataset, we can assume that there will always be just two distinct classes right?
For the current gradescope tests (I do not know if this will change, but it doesn't seem so), there are only binary class datasets. In previous semesters, we have had multi class datasets though.
What about varying threshold choices? Couldn't that, which we all do differently, also determine which attribute is chosen?

title: Value to split on
body: I am not sure how to find the value to perform the split. Is there something I am overlooking? I can't possibly try every single possible value and calculate the information gain in each of them. Or is that how I am supposed to do it?

comments.body:
You are going to first need to try every attribute to split on and for each one of those you then need to find the best threshold to split on. As stated in the assignment outlines for testing thresholds there are two options: "Note that since the attributes are continuous, you’ll need to select a threshold to split on. You
can do this by trying all possible thresholds (unique attribute values for the data set) or select
some finite number of cutoffs (try at least twenty)." So you could try every threshold for every attribute or some set amount >= 20 for every attribute. You likely will need to calculate the info gain for each one of these and pick the one that gives the most info gain.

title: Binary class value
body: Is the class label always binary in all the test sets (i.e. only has 2 class values)? Or can there be like 3, 4, etc. class values in the test sets?

comments.body: It's always best to handle multiple classes. That being said, I think this semester, the autograder only checks against the election dataset and the basic dataset, both of which are binary. In previous semesters, there have been datasets with multiple classes, so if you want to be really safe you can just code it for multiple classes.
Does this mean that we can assume that all rows have a binary label, and there are no None values, or is that something we should handle as well?

I think it would be wise to assume that None values might exist (even for class labels, though I doubt that's the case since checking classification would be impossible), and also assume that there could be multiple class values, just in case the autograder checks for that.

title: Lecture 2 Heuristic Search
body:
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

What does a tighter heuristic mean?

comments.body: I believe a "tighter" heuristic means a more strict estimation of the actual value, thus, de-prioritizing or eliminating more potential paths since the pool of options that fit in the range is less.

Let say here are two heuristic. One is really "tighter" called H1 and another one is really "un-tighter" called H2. 

If you want to find a optimal path, using H1 will lets you be significantly fast to get close to the optimal solution, but hard to say to truly return the optimal solution. 

However, if you use H2, which is really "un-tighter", each time the returned results from H2 are vague, even though the are all on the right tracks, which makes you run the searching with many more times. In other words, using H2 takes more time but never too fast to miss the optimal solution. Using H1 means that your step is huge so that you can get close to the optimal solution in a short time but possibly miss the optimal solution as well. 

HTH :)

title: Question about directions for HW6
body:
"If splitting on a particular attribute/threshold combination
will result in a leaf node that has fewer examples, you should not use it at that part of the tree" 

I'm having trouble what to do if this case happens in my code since I am confused on what to return in my recursion if this is true. 

![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)
When the stopping criteria is reached, I'm not completely sure what type of node to return, or what value to return at all.

comments.body:
Hi, let say in the case of the following decision tree, we have:
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

In our program, the whole tree only has two kinds of node, which are decision node (Class DecisionNode in codes, white node in the pic) and leaf node (Class LeafNode in codes, the grey nodes in the pic).

The function of creating node, which is the part that you need to implement, should judge the dataset that given by last recursion are still valid to be splitted into two smaller nodes, or already reach the stopping criteria to be considered as a leaf node. In a word, if it reach the stopping conditions (in our case, when info gain is useless or the number of dataset is less than given `min`), we need to create a object of class LeafNode given the dataset. HTH :)

title: Attribute error
body:
![Screenshot%202022-12-13%20at%2010.23.35%20PM.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

Please help, do not know what is wrong...

comments.body: I believe it is because the basic test data file found on Moodle used on those test have an attribute called 'id' and it should be ignored. Your code isn't ignoring it so it causes the error. Looking up "id_name" in decision_tree.py should help.
Thanks for replying, but I did check all my codes, and did not find any place I have used "id_name". I belive I did ignore it though please advise.

Ah, then in that case you were supposed to use it. When we iterate through the attributes, we want to make sure we skip the attribute whose name is the same as the value that will be stored in "id_name". So in your "findtheBestAttributes" when you have 
```
if header == self.class_name or header == 'Town':
    continue
```
You'd also want to check if header is equal to self.id_name. 

In the towns dataset there is no id so id_name isn't used.  However, the autograder is also tested on the basic test dataset which has an id named "id", so we have that self.id_name="id". Your code doesn't skip the "id" column and continue to the column named "first", thus giving the error.
Nick, Thank you so much!

title: Quick Beam Search Question
body:
In local beam search, part of the procedure is to:

At each iteration, generate the successors of all k states
- If anyone is a goal state, stop; otherwise, select the k best
successors from the complete list and repeat 

Does 'k best successors' here mean the 1 best successor for each k states? Or the k best successors out of all successors generated from all k states?

Thanks for the clarification

title: Quiz 5
body:
Why might this be wrong?
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

comments.body: KB doesn't necessarily always have to be true whenever alpha is true. However, KB can't be true when alpha is false, which is why "alpha is true under all models where KB is true" is the right answer, because that implies that KB is strictly a subset of alpha - and hence the KB can't take true values when alpha doesn't.
I see. Thank you.

title: Probability primer!
body:
![Screen%20Shot%202022-12-14%20at%207.16.36%20PM.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)
Can someone tell me how they solve this one?
Thanks!

comments.body:
You can rewrite P(m, a) using marginalization:
P(m, a, p, e) + P(m, a, -p, e) + P(m, a, p, -e) + P(m, a, -p, -e)

Then, just rewrite each of the joint prob terms above as a conditional probability of each variable given it's parents and plug in the appropriate values from the CPTs.

title: Inference by enumeration
body:
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

I understand how we did join R, but can't understand join T. Can someone explain how we got P(R,T,L) by doing join T on P(R,T) ,and P(L|T)?

In order to get P(R,T,L), will we not need to do P(L | T ,R) X P(R, T)?

comments.body: Yeah so any node is conditionally independent of its non-descendants given its parents and L's only parent is T. As a result we only need to multiply P(R, T) by P(L|parents) = P(L|T) instead of by P(L| R, T).
Oh that makes sense, thank you!

Isn't it the case that we need to multiply P(L|T) by P(T), not by P(R,T)? It seems as if values in the P(R,T) table are being directly multiplied with numbers in the P(L|T) table. Why can we do this? Why do we not need to marginalize T first?

Start with the basic conditional probability rule that P(A|B) = P(A, B) / P(B).

Rearrange, P(A, B) = P(A|B)P(B). Following this rule with our bayes net, P(L, R, T) = P(L|R, T)P(R, T). Since L is conditionally independent of R given parent T, we know P(L|R,T) is actually equivalent to P(L|T), as R being considered does not impact it.

This is why we can multiply P(L|T) * P(R, T). I think?!
I see! That seems like a good explanation. Thanks.

title: Hw2 Primer
body:
What is the solution of this question?

What would the above quantity be for a Connect-383 game played with m rows and n columns? Write your answer in terms of m and n rather than b and d.

Thanks

comments.body: There are a total of m*n possible moves as you have m rows and n columns. The player can, however, only choose the column and not the row thereby making n possible choices. Therefore, instead of O(b^d), the branching factor b becomes n, and the depth is mn which means the final answer is O(n^(mn)).Hope this helps

title: Approximate inference
body: In what ways is Rejection sampling better than Likelihood Weighting?

comments.body: It’s not. It just avoids unecessary sample creation.

Rejection sampling can easily be parallelized and can be used to generate samples from any distribution, regardless of whether it is easy to directly sample from the distribution. 

Likelihood sampling is better in cases where you can save time by not generating rejected samples in the first place.
Likelihood weighting avoids generating unnecessary samples , not rejection sampling, right?

title: Difference Between Forward checking and Arc consistency
body: Title. I am kind of unsure if they are the same thing. Or are 2 separate concepts

conversation.name: Difference Between Forward checking and Arc consistency

comments.body:
I believe that forward checking is, after an assignment to a variable, a single check to see if the updated domains of only its constraint neighbors still have valid colors. If none are left, backtrack. 

With arc consistency, it's a recursive process where we continue to check every single neighbor with an updated domain to see if when A updated, for every possible value of A, there is a non-conflicting possible value for each B neighbor. That's the arc consistency part, from A->B. Any conflicting values get removed like with forward checking, but when their domain is updated, it checks its own  neighbors and its updated neighbors so on until either there's no possibilities left or there is no inconsistencies

title: Resolution Algorithm
body:
Can anyone explain to me how to use the resolution algorithm to solve this/ what I did wrong?
![Screen%20Shot%202022-12-15%20at%209.40.30%20AM.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)
Thank you

comments.body: Here you have 3 Ds. In my opinion, the way to solve 3 Ds is to find a single D with two Ds like Not A U D with A U W then we have D U W and we make DUW with not WUD then we have single D here. Now you can Not DUS and single D to have single S. S with Not S then the problem is solved.

Part of getting a contradiction is including your assumption into the KB. I do not see an S or not S at the start. For example, if you assumed not S at the start, and you see (not D or S) you know not D must be true. You can whittle your way down to (D and not D), a clear contradiction.

title: Quiz 3 Q1
body:
Please advise. I think the answer is wrong.  The reason is:

Finding a solution to a Rubik's cube is an example of a constraint satisfaction problem because it involves assigning values to variables in such a way that all constraints are satisfied. In this case, the variables are the positions and orientations of the cube's individual pieces, and the constraints are the rules of the game, such as the requirement that each face of the cube must have a uniform color. To solve the puzzle, the values of the variables must be assigned in such a way that all constraints are satisfied, resulting in a solved Rubik's cube.


Instead I think Scheduling meetings for a group of UCAs is not an example of a constraint satisfaction problem. A constraint satisfaction problem is a problem in which a set of variables must be assigned values in such a way that all constraints are satisfied. Scheduling meetings for a group of UCAs does not involve assigning values to variables in order to satisfy constraints, so it does not fit the definition of a constraint satisfaction problem. Examples of constraint satisfaction problems include finding a solution to a Rubik's cube, solving Sudoku puzzles, and making seating assignments.

comments.body:
Finding a solution to a Rubik's cube is not dependent upon how the cubes are colored (CSP), but rather how to go from an unsolved state to a solved state.

UCAs each have their own schedules (constraints), and thus, scheduling meetings for a group of UCAs is a CSP. We must find a time that allows for all UCAs to be available.

title: Week 9 Quiz
body:
![image.png](https://campuspro-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/.../image.png)

Can someone explain why my answer is wrong, and the given answer is correct? Would really appreciate it!

comments.body: Because there's randomness in the move. Even if we choose to 'go right', there's a 0.1 chance we stay in the same state and a 0.1 chance we go to (3,2). If we 'go down' at (3,3), it is guaranteed that we end up in a different state.
If we go down at (3,3) isn't there a chance of us staying in the same state with a probability of 0.8?
that'd be if we go up, since we'd collide with the 'boundary' of the state space
if we go down at 3,3 then we could either move to 3,2 with a prob of 0.8, or to 4,3 /2,3 with a prob of 0.1
